materials.name: Course Details
materials.description: Units: 3; CSU/UC transferrable; Letter Grade Only. Duration: August 26 - Dec 15 (16 weeks including finals). Lecture: MW – 7:00 – 8:25 pm.

materials.name: Course Description
materials.description: Vector approach to static equilibrium of rigid bodies, forces, couples in two and three- dimensional space. Application of equilibrium principles to trusses, frames, and machines. Calculation of center-of-mass and centroid. Friction, moment of inertia, distributed and concentrated loads. Forces in cables and beams. Fluid statics. Introduction to virtual work. PRE-REQUISITES: PHYS 4A and MATH 181 (Calc 2).

materials.name: Required Materials
materials.description: Textbook: Engineering Mechanics: Statics, by R.C. Hibbeler, 15th ed. Other materials: Standard note-taking supplies, a scientific calculator that is NCEES/SAT/ACT approved (e.g., TI-36, TI-84), a straight-edge. Quad rule pad (graph paper) for completing homework is highly recommended.

materials.name: Student Learning Objectives
materials.description: Students are required to: be able to draw free-body diagrams of rigid bodies; apply equations of static equilibrium to two- and three- dimensional problems; determine centroids by integration; expand the usage of equations of static equilibrium to distributed loads and submerged areas; determine internal forces in trusses, frames and machines; analyze systems involving friction such as wedges, belts and screws; use parallel-axis theorem to calculate moment of inertia of structural members; apply principle of virtual work to solve equilibrium problems; analyze a typical truss to determine the force in a truss member; draw a free body diagram for a multi-force member and determine reactions.

materials.name: Grading Scale
materials.description: Homework: 10%, Midterm 1: 15%, Midterm 2: 15%, Midterm 3: 15%, Project: 20%, Final: 25%. Grade Scale: 90-100 (A), 80-89 (B), 70-79 (C), 60-69 (D), <59 (F).
